title: The 19.6% Trap: Structural Allocative Failure and the End of Cross-Subsidization in Vermont’s Healthcare Market
summary: The Vermont healthcare ecosystem has entered a phase of terminal economic instability. With residents spending 19.6% of their income on premiums to fund a system defined by 'allocative failure' and 262% price markups, this analysis argues that the Fee-For-Service model has rendered commercial cross-subsidization mathematically impossible.

children.text: The Vermont healthcare ecosystem has entered a phase of terminal economic instability. The recent public rupture between Blue Cross Blue Shield of Vermont (BCBSVT) and the University of Vermont Medical Center (UVMMC) is not a standard contract dispute; it is a symptom of systemic 'Allocative Failure.' With residents spending 19.6% of their household income on insurance premiums—the highest rate in the United States and nearly double the national average—the market has ceased to function as a mechanism for value and has become a mechanism for extraction.
I. The Precipitating Crisis: A Market Without Substitutes

The catalyst for this analysis is the unprecedented 'VT Affordable Care' marketing campaign launched by BCBSVT. By explicitly urging members to bypass the state’s flagship academic medical center in favor of independent facilities, the insurer has broken the tacit omertà of the healthcare industry. This move was born of necessity, not strategy; BCBSVT reportedly paid out $35 million weekly in claims in 2024, ending the year with a $62.1 million deficit.

However, the insurer’s financial distress is merely a lagging indicator of a deeper market pathology: the violation of the Law of One Price. In a functional, competitive market, identical goods—such as a standard 3T MRI scan without contrast—should command near-identical prices regardless of the vendor. In Vermont, market power has distorted this principle beyond recognition.

body.title: The Price of Leverage: 2025 Market Rates

children.text: The price differential between UVMMC and independent facilities represents a 262% markup for an identical service. In classical economics, this arbitrage opportunity would drive consumers to the lower-cost provider. This has not happened because UVMMC functions as a Differentiated Oligopoly. It controls approximately two-thirds of all hospital spending in Vermont. Because UVMMC is the sole provider of 'must-have' services (Level 1 Trauma, Burn Unit, NICU), it possesses immense leverage over payers, effectively bundling unique services with commoditized ones.
II. The Root Pathology: The Toxicity of Fee-For-Service (FFS)

While the high prices are the symptom, the disease is the incentive structure itself. The Fee-For-Service (FFS) model is the primary driver of Vermont’s healthcare inflation. Under FFS, healthcare providers are remunerated based on the volume and intensity of services provided, not the health outcomes achieved. This creates a fundamental misalignment between the provider’s financial health and the patient’s economic well-being.

The $6,520 MRI is not priced based on the cost of production; it is priced based on the hospital’s need to cross-subsidize other losing ventures. The MRI machine becomes a 'cash cow' that must be protected from competition.

This leads to Physician-Induced Demand (PID). In a vertical integration model like the UVM Health Network, the physician is also an employee of the revenue-seeking entity. A physician, aware of the hospital's financial goals, is implicitly incentivized to refer a patient to the internal (expensive) lab rather than an external (cheap) one. Because the patient is shielded from the full cost by insurance (Moral Hazard), Allocative Inefficiency occurs: society spends $6,500 for a service that costs $1,800 to produce.
III. The Demographic Cliff: The Failure of Cross-Subsidization

The hospital lobby argues that high commercial prices are necessary to offset the underpayment from Medicaid and Medicare. However, this logic is mathematically bankrupt in Vermont. Cross-subsidization functions like a pyramid scheme: it requires a broad base of commercially insured, working-age people to support the narrower tip of elderly and Medicaid patients. Vermont’s pyramid is inverting.

body.title: The Wyman Report: Demographic & Solvency Data

children.text: As the commercial base shrinks, the 'tax' required from each remaining worker rises exponentially. This is why premiums have hit 19.6% of income. We are reaching the mathematical limit of extraction. If premiums rise further, the healthy risk pool will exit the market (adverse selection), leaving only the sick, which drives premiums even higher—a classic Death Spiral.

BCBSVT’s attempt to solve this via 'shopping' is a weak solution to a structural problem. The solution requires a fundamental shift in the economic architecture. First, Vermont must abandon Fee-For-Service for Global Budgets (The Maryland Model). Under this model, the state sets a Total Revenue Cap for the hospital (e.g., $2.5 Billion/year). This flips the incentive: an MRI becomes a cost, not a profit, motivating the hospital to reduce unnecessary utilization.

Second, the state must mandate Site Neutral Payments. A Level 3 Office Visit should be reimbursed at the same rate whether it occurs in a hospital outpatient department or an independent clinic. Finally, routine care should be pushed out to low-cost community settings, while complex care is centralized at UVMMC, reserving the high-cost infrastructure for high-acuity needs.

We can no longer afford the $6,500 MRI. Not because we lack the money, but because the demographic math of Vermont dictates that every dollar wasted on inefficiency is a dollar stolen from the solvency of the state itself.
